content.description: This is the last route route from the left on the slab wall, just right of Slide. Begin on the bouldery, somewhat chossy start. Climb the slab to the anchors.
High first bolt; this route stays with you and makes you think. Sure, there are good rest stances, but you have to leave them sooner or later. Hard for vertically-challenged midgets.
content.location: Second route from the left on the slabby section of the Playground wall

content.description: Second route from the left. Climb over several bulges to the anchors.
content.protection: 6 bolts + anchors. Anchors are flexing on 3.12.19. Wait for glue-ins before doing this route.

content.description: Climb knobs and edges to the anchors.  Mangy rock down low leads to plain ol' fun above.
content.location: Starts just left of Tire Swing, slightly down the hill from Teeter Totter, up left of a large hueco at eye level.

content.description: Pinches lead to a long-ish move mid-route
content.location: leftmost route on the Playground wall

content.description:
Tons o fun the entire way.

This route starts off as an awkward flake with a few face holds to a decent sized ledge. From there, enter the chimney to experience secure climbing that will leave you smiling the whole way. Exit the chimney and step onto a ledge, soaking in the view. From here, climb a short flake to the anchors. Beware of the pricker bush on the ledge.
content.protection: Nuts and cams, the biggest cam I used was #3 camalot. This route protects very easily. Bolted anchors at the top.
content.location: Right of "Crack the Whip", just look for the big chimney!

content.description: The route begins on a slightly overhanging rock and steepens as you go.  Enjoy bigger moves and bigger holds on steeper rock as you near the anchors, great introduction to pulling on steep jug-hauls in the red!
content.protection: 5 bolts with 2 meat hooks at top
content.location: When you walk up the trail from the main road, this is the juggy and steep line that will be right in front of you.  Note 2 more sport routes to the right, including a crimpy 12a,are the last routes on the wall before the slabs.

content.description: A good route to try if Monkey Bars went well for you.  Enjoy fun climbing on jugs up the every steepening wall.  Save a little mojo for the crux mantle at the top!
Short and crimpy. Moving fast is a good strategy for success! Â Originally graded 5.12a.
content.location: To the right of Capture the Flag, the last route on the wall before the slabs.

content.description:
A rarity for the area: a cool, tough, overhung trad route. Follow a discontinuous crack-like feature (maybe more of a narrow water groove) through the overhanging terrain with frequent crimps and jugs. Crack gloves strongly recommended, as the "crack" is rough, jagged, and likely critical in the crux about 25-30 ft up.

Tends to be a bit sandy in spots, as small features continue to break and crumble due to a lack of traffic. Still, a great climb even with a little sand here and there.
content.protection: Ring anchors. Cams from 0.4-2 (double 0.75 and 1), will take tricams and nuts as well.
content.location: 5ft left of Jungle Gym, at the base of the vertical "crack"

content.description: Pretty powerful climbing on steep rock with lots and lots of edges and crimps.
content.location: Just to the right of Monkey Bars

content.description: Easy slab section for the first half of the climb leads to tricky 5.11 slab moves.
content.location: Slabby section of the playground wall, just to the right of the crack climb in the dihedral(Octopus tag)
